facts.text: Appellant was a member of the Bombay Medical Service, Class II and employee of the State of Maharashtra, posted at Civil Hospital, Ahmedabad in 1943 and in charge of Medico-Legal Section on February 18, 1950.
On January 19, 1950, one Nabimahomed complained to Mr. Rathod, Sub-Inspector of Police Anti-Corruption Branch, Ahmedabad.
Surgeon-General forwarded report of Sub-Inspector Rathod and appellant's representation to State Government by letter dated February 1, 1950, recommending suspension.
Recommendation approved by Minister for Health and Chief Minister.
By letter dated February 13, 1950, Deputy Secretary informed Surgeon-General that appellant should be suspended with immediate effect pending further orders.
Surgeon-General issued order dated February 16, 1950 to Civil Surgeon, Ahmedabad to place appellant under suspension from date of receipt.
Civil Surgeon issued office order suspending appellant with effect from afternoon of February 18, 1950, directing handover of charge to Mr. S. S. Doctor.
On August 21, 1950, Government directed subsistence allowance at specified rates from February 19, 1950 onwards, plus dearness and house rent allowances.
On May 6, 1950, sanction given for prosecution under s. 161 IPC.
On February 26, 1951, appellant convicted by First Class City Magistrate, Ahmedabad, sentenced to one day's imprisonment and fine of Rs. 1000/-.
Appellant's appeal to Sessions Court dismissed.
Revision to Bombay High Court allowed, conviction and sentence set aside.
On March 14, 1952, appellant represented for reinstatement.
Government applied for leave to appeal to Supreme Court, rejected; special leave also rejected on October 13, 1952.
On November 27, 1952, Government issued order on subsistence allowance.
On February 20, 1953, Government directed departmental enquiry; Civil Surgeon appointed Inquiry Officer to complete within three months.
Departmental inquiry delayed; dismissal order made on February 11, 1960.
Before conclusion of departmental inquiry, appellant gave notice under s. 80 CPC.
On April 11, 1953, appellant filed suit for declaration that suspension illegal, continued in service, claiming remuneration till reinstatement.
Shah, J. held suspension illegal, granted declaration and decree for Rs. 51,135.28 with interest and costs, up to dismissal date February 11, 1960.
Respondent appealed; Appellate Bench (Chief Justice and Mody, J.) allowed appeal, held suspension valid under Rule 151, suit barred by limitation, dismissed suit with costs.
Appeal to Supreme Court by certificate.

legal_issues.text: Whether Government had the power to suspend the appellant by order dated February 13, 1950 pending enquiry into alleged misconduct.
Whether the order of suspension came to an end on February 15, 1952 upon acquittal by High Court, entitling appellant to full pay till dismissal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Power to suspend is not an implied term in ordinary contract between master and servant; can only exist by statute, statutory rules, or express contract term. No express provision in Bombay Civil Services Rules for suspension pending enquiry.
Rule 151 applies only to suspension by way of penalty, not interim suspension.
Suspension ordered pending criminal inquiry ended automatically on acquittal by High Court on February 15, 1952.

respondent_arguments.text: Government had inherent power to suspend and withhold full remuneration under Rule 151 of Bombay Civil Services Rules.
Suit barred under Article 14 of Indian Limitation Act.

court_reasoning.text: Power to suspend (forbid work) not implied in ordinary contract but exists if in statute/rules/contract. Suspension temporarily suspends master-servant relation. Employer can suspend pending inquiry; payment depends on rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Government as employer has power to suspend public servant pending enquiry; authority that appoints can suspend.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 151 applies to all suspensions, including interim, as per language and context with Rules 153,156; similar to Fundamental Rule 53 upheld in R.P. Kapur.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suspension order dated February 13, 1950 valid; entitled to subsistence allowance not exceeding 1/4 pay.

court_reasoning.text: Suspension order 'pending further orders' does not end automatically on acquittal; requires terminating order. Distinguished Narayan Prasad case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suspension continued till dismissal; no right to reinstatement or full pay post-acquittal.

holdings.text: State Government had power to suspend appellant pending enquiry under general principles and Rule 151 Bombay Civil Services Rules.
Suspension order did not terminate automatically on acquittal; appellant not entitled to full pay post-acquittal.

precedents_cited.relevance: General law on suspension not implied in ordinary contract.

R. P. Kapur v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Fundamental Rule 53 applies to all suspensions including interim; analogous to Bombay Rules 151,152.
Principle of suspension in master-servant relation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Boston Deep Sea Fishing and Ice Co. v. Ansell
precedents_cited.relevance: Judgment of Cotton L.J. on suspension.

precedents_cited.case_name: Narayan Prasad Rewany v. State of Orissa
precedents_cited.relevance: Suspension under specific rule ended on termination of criminal proceedings; different facts and rule here.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Notice given by appellant before suit.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Civil Services Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Govern payments during suspension, apply to interim and penalty suspensions; empower withholding pay beyond subsistence allowance.

statutes_cited.name: Fundamental Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogous to Bombay Rules; apply to all suspensions.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Suit allegedly barred; not decided as claim meritless.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding Bombay High Court Appellate Bench decision that suspension was valid under Rule 151, did not end on acquittal, and appellant's suit claim devoid of merit.

key_quotes.text: The power to suspend, in the sense of a right to forbid a servant to work, is not an implied term in an ordinary contract between master and servant...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: States general principle of law on suspension.

key_quotes.text: Rule 151 empowers the State Government to withhold pay for the period of interim suspension but the Government servant is entitled under that rule to a subsistence allowance...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Holds Rule 151 applies to interim suspension.

key_quotes.text: The order of suspension could not be automatically terminated but it could have only been terminated by another order of the Government.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects automatic end of suspension on acquittal.
